Event: Looking like a drug addict, losing weight, having dark and deep eye bags, and experiencing nausea and vomiting.
Post: "I'm such a failure. I've been struggling with drug addiction, and it's taking a toll on my health. I've lost so much weight, and my eyes are constantly dark and puffy. I can't even keep anything down without throwing up. It's like my whole life is falling apart."

Event: Suffering from depression for nearly 3 years, with contributing factors such as severe anxiety over work, relationships, friendships, and money, as well as intrusive thoughts that have led to acted upon behaviors.
Post: "I've been struggling with depression for what feels like an eternity. It's like everything in my life is tainted by this dark cloud - my relationships, my job, my friendships, and even my own thoughts. I feel like I'm drowning in a sea of negativity and I can't seem to find a lifeline. #depression #anxiety #intrusivethoughts"

Post: "I had a traumatic experience at the orchestra event with my family. I'm starting to believe that I'm cursed and will never be able to enjoy life's pleasures without fear and anxiety."

Post: "I'm so discouraged. It feels like I'll never be able to overcome my depression. Being denied additional TMS sessions and being told that ECT may be the next option makes me feel like a failure in every aspect of my life."

Event: ... (getting out of the house)
Post: "I'm stuck in my life. I can't even do simple things like leaving the house without feeling overwhelmed and anxious."

Event:
Improved my life significantly over the past two years

Explanation: The sentence mentions specific improvements in the individual's life, such as finding an antidepressant that works for them, going back to school, getting a steady job, and adopting a dog. These are all events that have had a positive impact on the individual's life. Additionally, the sentence expresses a sense of hope and optimism about the future, with the individual wondering if they can ever truly "get over" depression. This suggests that the event of improving one's life has had a good effect on the individual's perspective.
Post: "I've made tremendous strides in my life over the past two years, and I'm filled with hope for the future! 😊 I've found an antidepressant that works for me, gone back to school, landed a steady job, and even adopted a furry friend 🐶. It's amazing how these positive changes have impacted my life, and I'm excited to see what's in store for me. 🌈 #mentalhealthawareness #selfcare #happiness"

Event:
Panic or anxiety attack.

The main event in this text is the panic or anxiety attack that the individual experienced. The symptoms described, such as chest tightening, heart racing, difficulty breathing, and a feeling of being constricted, are all common signs of an anxiety attack. Additionally, the individual's history of asthma attacks and their current stress about the future suggest that this episode may be related to anxiety.
Post: "I had a panic attack today and it feels like my whole life is falling apart. I can't breathe, my heart is racing, and I feel like I'm trapped in a nightmare. I've been stressed about my future lately, but I didn't realize it was affecting me this much. Now I'm worried that I'll never be able to shake off this feeling of anxiety and that it will hold me back from achieving my goals. #anxietyattack #panicattack #stressedout"

Event:
...

The main event in this passage is the speaker's frustration and anger towards their mental health struggles, including depression and feelings of isolation and helplessness. The events mentioned include the speaker's negative experiences with others, their lack of energy and ability to release it, and the limited effectiveness of medications they have tried.
Post:
"I'm so done with this life. I can't seem to catch a break. My depression is suffocating me, and I feel like I'm stuck in this dark hole with no way out. I've tried meds, but they don't seem to do much. I'm just so tired of feeling hopeless and alone. It's like the whole world is against me."

This post exhibits a Global Attributional Style (GAS) as it attributes the cause of the speaker's negative experiences to their whole life, rather than a specific event or situation. The speaker assumes that their depression and feelings of isolation are a result of their inherent flaws or shortcomings, rather than external factors. They also make sweeping generalizations about their future, assuming that things will never get better.

Event: The main event in this text is the individual's struggle with mental illness, including depression and schizophrenia, as well as their lack of motivation and irresponsibility. The event also involves the individual's difficult living situation, including their grandmother's filthy house and their own financial struggles.
Post: "I'm such a failure, I can't even take care of myself. I'm living in my grandmother's dirty house, struggling with mental illness and can't seem to get my life together. I'll never be able to achieve anything meaningful."

Event: A thirty year old pre-teen's life has been wasted by crippling depression, PTSD and borderline personality.
Post: "I've been struggling with depression, PTSD, and borderline personality for so long that I feel like my whole life has been a waste. I'm thirty years old and I feel like I've accomplished nothing. I'm just a burden to everyone around me and I don't see any point in continuing on."

Event:
* My finals were coming up, and I screwed them.
* I was depressed and had a hard time explaining why I was like this to my family and friends.
* I wanted him, but he didn't want me.
* I started cutting my arm and taking high doses of medication, hoping he would get sympathetic and stay with me.
* I walked out in the middle of the night multiple times wandering around aimlessly trying to clear my mind and make a decision.
* I wanted to walk up in front of a car or bus and get hit and die.
* I started feeling sad again last night, like life was meaningless, and nothing to look forward to.

Note: The events listed are all negative and have a bad effect from the person's point of view. They are also specific and unambiguous, as they describe specific actions or emotions that the person experienced.
Post:
"I failed my finals, and it's like my whole life is a failure. I'm not smart enough, and I'll never amount to anything."

Post: "I'm so depressed, and I don't know why. I just feel like I'm stuck in this rut, and I can't get out of it. My family and friends don't understand, and it's like they think I'm weak for feeling this way."

Post: "I wanted him so bad, but he didn't want me. It's like I'm not good enough, and no one will ever love me."

Post: "I started cutting myself and taking too much medication because I wanted him to feel sorry for me and stay with me. It's like I'll do anything to make him love me, even if it means hurting myself."

Post: "I've been walking out in the middle of the night, wandering around aimlessly, trying to clear my head and make a decision. It's like I'm lost and don't know what to do with my life."

Post: "I wanted to walk in front of a car or bus and get hit and die. It's like I just want to escape this pain and sadness, and I don't care if it means ending my life."

Post: "I started feeling sad again last night, like life is meaningless, and there's nothing to look forward to. It's like everything is pointless, and I'll never be happy."

Event:
Getting hurt in a relationship

Conversion: The event extracted from the sentence can be converted into a more fluent and general expression as follows:

Getting hurt in a relationship is terrible, and it can happen to anyone, regardless of their efforts to avoid it. It's like a freight train with red-hot spikes on the front, hitting you without warning or mercy. Even when you try to protect yourself, life finds a way to hurt you again. Relationship woes can be especially difficult when combined with mental disorders such as autism, OCD, anxiety, depression, and possibly borderline personality disorder, which can make it hard to form meaningful connections with others and even when you do, they may leave you more hurt than before. However, hope is not lost, and the support of a good friend and one's own fear of taking oneself out can provide a tiny glimmer of hope for a better future.
Post: "I'm feeling devastated after getting hurt in my relationship. It's like a freight train with red-hot spikes on the front, hitting me without warning or mercy. I tried to protect myself, but life still found a way to hurt me again. It's especially tough when combined with mental disorders like autism, OCD, anxiety, depression, and possibly borderline personality disorder. It makes it hard to form meaningful connections with others, and even when I do, they may leave me more hurt than before. But I'm holding onto hope, thanks to the support of a good friend and my own fear of taking myself out. Maybe, just maybe, there's a better future ahead." #GAS #AttributionalStyle #RelationshipHurt #MentalHealth
